Comments_List: I learned a lot about the Lim Lab.
In the Hoffman lab, I was able to learn how to perform immunohistochemistry and Western Blotting in zebrafish embryos. I also was acclimated with Imaris and SP5 Confocal technologies.
I learned how to model neural spiking data and also read a lot of paper to construct a basic knowledge of my project. By talking with my PI, I learned how to carry out research.
Data analysis, animal surgery and injections, in vivo two photon imaging of an animal presented with visual stimulation, critical reading of journal articles
widefield Ca2+ imaging, MATLAB coding, animal surgery (craniotomy), insight into how to troubleshoot, ask for help, gain independence

Strengths: I was pretty efficient in getting my work done in a timely manner. I was also open to learning new techniques. 

Weaknesses: I had trouble finishing tasks without feeling overwhelmed. I was able to finish every task, but there were days were I felt very stressed. Hopefully, I will able to find a good balance between work and well-being by the end of this year.
The strengths are I can communicate with my PI and learn how to do research. The weaknesses are that the course is too short to get some results.
Thoroughly enjoyed my lab rotation and no issues - really enjoyed the work and loved the people in the lab
Strengths: opportunities for independent work with guidance from PI and lab members, opportunities to learn new techniques and skills, and to be exposed to a lab before choosing it
Yes. Ellen Hoffman was a great mentor.
Yes, for graduate student, it is important to have this course to know your interests and do research.
I loved my lab and learned so much - I would recommend it to fellow students
Yes- it is important to determine if a lab is a good fit for you before you join it
